docs.text: Tips for App Demo Record what you can This might be one that you've heard before. WHen running through an app demo, the last thing you want is to forgot something that causes an issue during the demo. Try to have the app hosted Even with having recorded the app demo, it will be nice to have a stable hosted version of the app. This will probably come in handy if someone has a question best answered with more app demo. Demo all Functionality Try to squeeze in as much of the features as you can. DOn't forgot to show off all the important features of the app.
docs.title: Tips for app Demo

docs.text: Hi there Why document? Documentation is going to be really important for any long term project. Even if you are the only one to work on a project, documentation is important because we forget things. If, on the other hand, you are part of a collaborative project, documentation becomes more important because others will need to understand the project. What to document Some of the basic things that should be documented are: App setup (if applicable) Starting the App Running the tests You might also add links to code: mkdocs.yml Docs Folder Or even code snippets: def base_url # "http://some_staging_thing" "http://localhost" end You could also document the creators/maintainers Name Position Contact Rusty Shackelford CIA Yeah Right! Add badges for monitoring: How to document There are a ton of documentation tools out there. THe majority of them (or all that I have seen) are built on markdown. Markdown is best described as an html shorthand (I guess? by me at least...). The frameworks that use markdown however are numerous. What you are looking at here is mkdocs. I created this presentation with mkdocs, because I think it might be the simplest. Personally, I am big fan of jekyll, which is another framework that might feel more familiar to ruby-ists. To decide on a documentation framework, you should pick one that the majority of the team is either familiar with, or comfortable learning.
docs.title: Intro

docs.text: Documentation is going to be really important for any long term project. Even if you are the only one to work on a project, documentation is important because we forget things. docs.text: There are a ton of documentation tools out there. THe majority of them (or all that I have seen) are built on markdown. Markdown is best described as an html shorthand (I guess? by me at least...). The frameworks that use markdown however are numerous. What you are looking at here is mkdocs. I created this presentation with mkdocs, because I think it might be the simplest. Personally, I am big fan of jekyll, which is another framework that might feel more familiar to ruby-ists. To decide on a documentation framework, you should pick one that the majority of the team is either familiar with, or comfortable learning.
docs.title: How to document

docs.text: How to Illustrate Technical Details of a Project You have a few tools here to create meaningful technical illustrations. I have an example using lucid chart, but you can also use Google draw (among many others I am sure). In practice, you might see/develop these technical diagrams before the project even starts
docs.title: Intro

docs.text: You have a few tools here to create meaningful technical illustrations. I have an example using lucid chart, but you can also use Google draw (among many others I am sure). In practice, you might see/develop these technical diagrams before the project even starts
